司.definition: to take charge of; to manage; department (under a ministry)

司各特.definition: Scott (name); Sir Walter Scott (1771-1832), Scottish romantic novelist

司天臺.definition: Observatory or Bureau of Astronomy (official title) from the Tang dynasty onwards

司寇.definition: minister of criminal justice (official rank in imperial China)

司徒.definition: minister of land and people (in ancient times)

司徒雷登.definition: John Leighton Stuart (1876-1962), second-generation American missionary in China, first president of Yenching University and later United States ambassador to China

司法部.definition: Ministry of Justice (PRC etc); Justice Department (USA etc)

司法院.definition: Judicial Yuan, the high court under the constitution of Republic of China, then of Taiwan

司爐.definition: stoker (worker operating a coal fire, esp. for a steam engine)

司職.definition: to serve in the role of; (sports) to play as (midfielder, defender etc)

司馬.definition: Minister of War (official title in pre-Han Chinese states); two-character surname Sima

司馬光.definition: Sima Guang (1019-1086), politician and historian of Northern Song, author of Comprehensive Mirror for aid in Government 資治通鑒|资治通鉴

司馬懿.definition: Sima Yi (179-251), warlord under Cao Cao and subsequently founder of the Jin dynasty

司馬承幀.definition: Sima Chengzhen (655-735), Daoist priest in Tang dynasty

司馬昭.definition: Sima Zhao (211-265), military general and statesman of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4]

司馬昭之心路人皆知.pinyin: Si1 ma3 Zhao1 zhi1 xin1 lu4 ren2 jie1 zhi1
司馬昭之心路人皆知.definition: lit. Sima Zhao's intentions are obvious to everyone (idiom); fig. an open secret

司馬法.definition: “Methods of Sima”, also called “Sima Rangju’s Art of War”, one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1], written by Sima Rangju 司馬穰苴|司马穰苴[Si1 ma3 Rang2 ju1]

司馬炎.definition: Sima Yan (236-290), founder and first emperor (265-290) of the Western Jin dynasty 西晉|西晋[Xi1 Jin4], posthumous name 晉武帝|晋武帝[Jin4 Wu3di4]

司馬穰苴.definition: Sima Rangju (c. 800 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), military strategist of the Qi State 齊國|齐国[Qi2 guo2] and author of “Methods of Sima” 司馬法|司马法[Si1 ma3 Fa3], one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1]

司馬談.definition: Sima Tan (-110 BC), Han dynasty scholar and historian, and father of 司馬遷|司马迁[Si1 ma3 Qian1]

司馬遷.definition: Sima Qian (145-86 BC), Han Dynasty historian, author of Records of the Grand Historian 史記|史记[Shi3 ji4], known as the father of Chinese historiography

司馬遼太郎.definition: SHIBA Ryotarō (1923-1996), Japanese author of historical novels
